data.title: What is your all-time favourite Science Fiction book?
data.text:
I have several all time favorites:

Lensman Series, E.E. 'Doc' Smith

The First SF of any kind I read as a kid.

Which led me to ...

Starship Troopers, not a favorite, -- it has never recovered from not being the Lensman.

But it led me to:

Stranger in a Strange Land, Robert Heinlein

Which led me to:

The Moon is a Harsh Mistress, Robert Heinlein

These are my emotional favorites from when I was 12-13 years old. Which led me to keep read SF through the years and that led me to:

Dhalgren, Samuel R. Delany -- my all time favorite. I have read it over 10 times, and each time it is a different experience.

There are many SF books that I regard as 'favourites' but Philip K. Dick's A Scanner Darkly is the one from which I consistently glean the most enjoyment.

Despite the fact that its SF links are tenuous (although a lot less ‘tenuous’ than some other SF novels I can think of), I still cannot understand why it rarely does well in SF top 10/100/200 lists.

Dune 1,5,6

Did not really like the ones by the son but I am reading them lol

I see many of my Favs here already.

Enders Game. Armor - Dorsi books.

I would also put "Brightness falls from the Air" by James Tiptree Jr.

and "Up the Walls of the World" by the same author.

The early "Pern" books

I have enjoyed the couple of Ian Banks culture novels that I have read.

I like the Far future books of Mike Resnick.

David Brin is real good - the first three Uplift.

Vernor Vinge and John Vinge

I am sure that more will come to mind as I have read about 500 books in my 38 years starting with the Hobit at 13.

The first Si fi books were battle Star galac becuase the TV show was about to start and I was still crazzed over Star Wars the movie.

Oh the Majipoor stuff

well the flood gates are open now lol

What is your all-time favorite Sci-Fi book?

Sorry, but I'm not too much into Fantasy sci-fi--so besides labeling my own book, I will state that at the age of 15 the best I ever read was "When Worlds Collide and After Worlds Collide" by Phillip Wylie & Edwin Balmer (1932-33). That was many years ago before I started to even ponder writing my own book.

My second all time favorite is a bit more recent. "In Death Ground" (1997) by David Weber and Steve White. The ultimate outer space high-tech Bug Invasion!

So to everyone across the entire planet--What is your all-time favorite sci-fi book?

Orbital Resonance?

Hello Lemming,

Glad to hear from someone else from Massachusetts. That's the second time I've seen someone list the name of that book, "Orbital Resonance" in the past week. Will check it out on Amazon. Must be good if it's your favorite.

Gregg

I have to agree with Knivesout here, it's darn near impossible to pick just one.

...However, if you put a gun to my head, the book that I would blurt out before you pulled the trigger would probably be "Snowcrash" by Neal Stephenson. It is especially one of my favorite books to re-read when I'm not in the mood for something new.

Matrix meets Mafia?

To: Archren,

Your favorite sounds like a real mind-bender. The idea that all pizza shops are owned by Cosa Nostra Pizza Inc. means you would really pay through the nose for pizza!

Neal Stephenson's book, "SnowCrash" sounds almost like a more vicious version of the movie-Demolition Man.

I too have read over again some of my favorites.

My third best favorite is "Renegade's Honor" by William Keith. It had to do with the Renegade Legions board games in the 1980's.

Greg

If i had the chance to read only one novel i would like it to be Flowers for Algernon !! The runner-up is the outstanding Dune ... but... i haven't had the chance to read much SF yet cause i'm a new fan!!

I think this topic was on here a long time ago and I'll be damned if I can remember what I chose as my favorite book back then. It's just a well, because I'm always changing my mind about what my favorite books are.

Anyway, the one science fiction book that has stuck with me over the past few years is A Deepness in the Sky by Vernor Vigne.
